Despite Xi Jinping's recent bellicose message to the Southern Theater Command, https://americanmilitarynews.com/2018/10/china-orders-south-china-sea-forces-to-prep-for-fighting-a-war/, Chinais unlikely to intentionally initiate a crisis before Jan 1 due to the recent political developments in the US midterm elections. Chinese officials have been shocked by the whiplash in Sino-US relations in the past year, especially regarding sanctions. They originally thought that Trump was an ideologically malleable but fundamentally predictable leader, so they have been surprised by his trade war. This means that they are much more likely to initiate a crisis at a time when there is more division of government after the swearing in of the 116th Congress after Jan 1. That being said a lethal conflict does not need to be premeditated, just poorly handled. But multiple close calls have already occurred and freedom of navigation exercises will continue through the end of 2018. That being said, RIMPAC has already occurred and no large scale military exercises are planned by either country, so the likelihood of a lethal conflict is fairly slim.

I agree with others here that the odds are high that something will eventually happen and at the same time low in the immediate future.  I think China's massive investment in this area and expansion of military exercises, trials of new military equipment, claims of threats from others, and military bases off the coast of the Philippines in the Spratly Islands, among other things, make it clear that they intend very much to claim and eventually enforce exclusive rights in this area.  And while I think Vietnam and Philippines can do very little on their own about this, I think the US and UK are continuing to move through the area in their "normal" way but on heightened alert to show that they don't plan to let China claim exclusive rights.  The fact that China is making a big deal about the "provocation" of a UK warship getting too close to the Paracel Islands, that they sent military vehicles to warn them off, suggests that China wants to continue to clearly stake to their claim but not yet actually enforce it.  The fact that the UK vessel was careful to stay exactly 12 nautical miles from the Island group in strict observation of an internationally recognized territorial limitation suggests that they are purposefully rejecting China's claims.  And will continue to do so.  And I think China will continue to expand their military, and in fact, this theater of aggression gives China the opportunity of openly expanding and exploring naval military development without unusual scrutiny (or at least any more than military agencies of various nations would otherwise give).  I think there is little likelihood for the time being of any slip up unless it comes from Vietnam or Philippines, and even then very small.  But eventually there will be some excuse of international political threat which will justify China's enforcement of their claims, and after having made them for years it will no doubt seem much more reasonable (to China and its allies) and justify warning shots.  And I imagine that the US and UK and others will then stand down rather than engage in direct confrontation unless there is some direct declaration of war already at hand.  The more realistic the threat, the less likely accidents are likely to happen unless they're staged on purpose to precipitate an event.  I think the high conflict times tend to be late spring and early fall, but I think things are likely to stay cool this year.

So I calculated a baseline of 5% from the number of years containing events that could reasonably result in a lethal confrontation since 1974 (my starting point for SCS disputes...the Paracels Invasion). Over the past 44 years there have been 10 years with such events (1974, 1975, 1983, 1988, 1995, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2017) which gives me P/A = 0.227. Of those ten years only two (1974 and 1988 contained an actual lethal confrontation) which gives me a P/B 0.2. To calculate the dependent probability 0.227 x 0.2 = 0.045 which I'll round up to 5%.

So I calculated a baseline of 5% from the number of years containing events that could reasonably result in a lethal confrontation since 1974 (my starting point for SCS disputes...the Paracels Invasion). Over the past 44 years there have been 10 years with such events (1974, 1975, 1983, 1988, 1995, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2017) which gives me P/A = 0.227. Of those ten years only two (1974 and 1988 contained an actual lethal confrontation) which gives me a P/B 0.2. To calculate the dependent probability 0.227 x 0.2 = 0.045 which I'll round up to 5%.

For this week, the question I chose is: “Will there be a lethal confrontation in the South or East China Sea between the military forces, militia, or law enforcement personnel of China and another country before 1 January 2019?”  I am predicting that there is 10% probability that this will occur.  Initially, before conducting any research, I assigned a much lower probability of this event happening, but the likelihood of a lethal confrontation is much greater than previously expected.  The Council on Foreign Relations argues that the territorial dispute over 8 islands between China and Japan, which is critical to U.S. interests, has escalated in the recent months.  Chinese vessels have increased incursions into the disputed waters and due to this, Japan has increased its military capabilities, such as radar and missile systems, which led to the same actions by China in response.  China has built large naval warships to guard its vessels to maintain strategic advantage, which has presented serious concerns to Japan.  Consequently, Chinese aircraft have approached Japan’s airspace over 570 times, which has caused the Japanese military to scramble its jets 199 times as a response.  Although these events are concerning, it is pertinent to many major powers, including the United States, that no lethal confrontation takes place, which would undoubtedly cause additional casualties between the two historical enemies.  Both countries stand on completely inverse ideological and political spectrums, which may or may not influence future confrontations.  But then again, territory and oil are essential assets.

The CIA World Factbook gives a good summation of each country's fiduciary status footprint (https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_government_budget). If it involved China's 'little blue men' or as jnmeade says Q-boat operations, I would put the number higher. Further, given Xi improvement over control of the military with the CMC downsizing and busting Xu Caihou and Guo Buoxiong, the likelihood of local commanders taking matters into their own hands is lower, but not completely eliminated due to army men who owe their position due to money rather than skill.

Normally, my money would be on yes, and the likely culprit would me Chinas version of the Maritime Militia. However Indonesian police have been hunting them in their fishing waters and seizing those to far away for a China Navy vessel to interfere.

The question limits the actors to official or government personnel, not fishermen, traders or such.  The greatest probability is if we get a couple of hot-heads who are overcome by events. Same thing could happen if we get a couple of Q-boat type operations run amok.  Likely won't be deliberate, more likely something that got out of control.
